How do I help my child with reading and maths if they're struggling?

Practical, evidence-based strategies for parents to support children struggling with reading and mathematics, including when to seek professional help and how to work effectively with schools.

Understanding Learning Challenges

Many children experience temporary difficulties with reading or maths at some point. The key is early identification and appropriate support. Most learning challenges can be addressed successfully when caught early, but ignoring them can lead to frustration, low confidence, and entrenched difficulties.

Remember that struggling doesn't mean your child isn't capable—it often means they need different approaches or additional time to master concepts. With the right support, most children can overcome these challenges and develop strong skills.

Supporting Reading Development

Identifying Reading Difficulties

Look for these signs that your child might need extra reading support:

  • Slow or labored reading with frequent mistakes
  • Limited comprehension of simple texts
  • Avoidance of reading activities
  • Difficulty recognizing common words
  • Frustration or anxiety when reading
  • Poor spelling or writing skills

Effective Reading Support Strategies

Focus on building confidence and skills gradually:

  • Daily reading practice: 15-20 minutes of enjoyable reading together
  • Phonics awareness: Play sound games and practice letter-sound relationships
  • Vocabulary building: Discuss new words and their meanings during reading
  • Comprehension strategies: Ask questions about what you've read and make predictions
  • Fluency practice: Read familiar texts repeatedly to build speed and accuracy
  • Positive reinforcement: Celebrate effort and small improvements

Reading Resources and Activities

  • Decodable books: Books that match your child's current reading level
  • Audiobooks: Listen together to build comprehension and vocabulary
  • Reading games: Word recognition games and phonics apps
  • Library visits: Regular trips to choose books at the right level
  • Reading logs: Track reading progress and celebrate achievements

Supporting Mathematics Learning

Identifying Maths Difficulties

Maths struggles can show up in different ways:

  • Difficulty remembering basic facts (addition, multiplication)
  • Struggles with number concepts or place value
  • Problems understanding word problems
  • Avoidance of maths activities or homework
  • Frustration with maths tasks
  • Poor performance on maths assessments

Effective Maths Support Strategies

Make maths concrete and relevant to build understanding:

  • Use concrete materials: Counters, blocks, and manipulatives to demonstrate concepts
  • Real-life connections: Incorporate maths into cooking, shopping, and games
  • Regular practice: Short, daily practice sessions rather than long, intensive sessions
  • Problem-solving approach: Teach strategies for tackling maths problems
  • Visual representations: Drawings, diagrams, and number lines to show concepts
  • Positive attitudes: Emphasize that maths is about thinking and problem-solving

Maths Resources and Activities

  • Maths games: Board games, card games, and online maths activities
  • Everyday maths: Measuring ingredients, telling time, counting money
  • Maths apps: Interactive programs that provide immediate feedback
  • Worksheets and practice books: Targeted practice for specific skills
  • Maths journals: Writing about maths thinking and problem-solving

Creating a Supportive Learning Environment

Emotional Support

Learning difficulties often affect confidence and motivation:

  • Positive reinforcement: Praise effort and strategies, not just correct answers
  • Growth mindset: Emphasize that abilities can improve with practice
  • Reduce anxiety: Create low-pressure learning situations
  • Celebrate progress: Notice and acknowledge small improvements
  • Model persistence: Show how you approach challenging tasks

Structured Support

Establish helpful routines and systems:

  • Consistent schedule: Regular times for learning activities
  • Organized space: Quiet, well-equipped area for focused work
  • Clear expectations: Age-appropriate goals and time limits
  • Break down tasks: Divide work into manageable chunks
  • Progress tracking: Visual charts or logs to show improvement

Working with Your School

Initial Communication

Start conversations with teachers early:

  • Share specific observations about your child's struggles
  • Ask about classroom performance and behaviors
  • Discuss what support is already available at school
  • Learn about the curriculum and teaching approaches
  • Understand assessment results and what they mean

Collaborative Support Planning

Work with teachers to create a support plan:

  • Additional classroom support: Extra help during lessons
  • Modified assignments: Adjusted workload or difficulty level
  • Specialized programs: Reading intervention or maths support groups
  • Progress monitoring: Regular check-ins on improvement
  • Home-school communication: Regular updates and shared strategies

Understanding School Resources

Most Queensland schools offer various support options:

  • Learning support teachers: Specialized help for students with difficulties
  • Reading specialists: Targeted reading intervention programs
  • Maths coaches: Additional maths support and tutoring
  • Student support services: Guidance officers and counselors
  • External referrals: Access to speech pathologists or educational psychologists

When to Seek Professional Help

Signs It's Time for Assessment

Consider professional evaluation if:

  • Difficulties persist despite consistent support for 6+ months
  • Your child shows significant frustration or avoidance
  • Learning gaps are widening rather than closing
  • You suspect a specific learning difficulty (dyslexia, dyscalculia)
  • School support alone isn't sufficient

Professional Assessment Options

  • Educational psychologists: Comprehensive learning assessments
  • Speech pathologists: For reading and language difficulties
  • Occupational therapists: For fine motor or organizational challenges
  • Pediatricians: Medical evaluation to rule out underlying issues
  • Specialist teachers: Expert assessment of specific learning areas

Funding and Support Services

Various funding options may be available:

  • NDIS (National Disability Insurance Scheme): For eligible disabilities
  • Queensland Government funding: Through disability services
  • Private health insurance: May cover assessments or therapy
  • School-based funding: Additional support through school budgets

Balancing Support with Independence

Avoiding Over-Help

While support is important, too much help can be counterproductive:

  • Let them struggle productively: Allow appropriate challenge to build resilience
  • Guide rather than do: Ask questions that lead to understanding
  • Gradual release: Start with full support and gradually reduce it
  • Build confidence: Celebrate independent problem-solving

Encouraging Independence

Help your child develop self-help strategies:

  • Self-assessment: "What did you find tricky about this?"
  • Strategy development: "How could you approach this differently?"
  • Help-seeking skills: Knowing when and how to ask for help
  • Goal setting: Setting achievable learning targets

Long-Term Perspective

Patience and Persistence

Learning progress takes time and varies for each child:

  • Focus on growth: Look for gradual improvement over time
  • Celebrate effort: Recognize hard work and persistence
  • Maintain balance: Ensure learning support doesn't dominate family life
  • Stay positive: Model confidence in your child's ability to improve

Building Lifelong Skills

The goal is more than just improving grades:

  • Learning strategies: Effective approaches to tackling challenges
  • Resilience: Ability to persist through difficulties
  • Help-seeking: Knowing when and how to ask for support
  • Confidence: Belief in their ability to learn and improve

Remember: You're Not Alone

Many parents face similar challenges, and most children who struggle with reading or maths go on to succeed with appropriate support. The important thing is recognizing difficulties early and seeking help proactively.

Schools, teachers, and support services are there to help. Don't hesitate to ask questions and advocate for your child's needs. With the right combination of home support, school resources, and professional help when needed, most children can overcome learning challenges and develop strong skills.

Your involvement and advocacy make a significant difference. By staying engaged and maintaining a positive, supportive approach, you're helping your child build the foundation for lifelong learning success.
